items.synopsis: A combination of old-fashioned espionage and high-tech surveillance was meant to keep Israelis safe. But when Hamas smashed through the fence, all the systems seemed to fail.

items.synopsis: Federal public servants tend to earn less than other Australians who are the same age and who have similar educational achievements, ABC analysis shows.

title.children: How much is a public servant worth? Data suggests it's more than they are paid

items.synopsis: A cruel and incurable disease took former TV personality Fiona MacDonald's voice, and her trademark quick wit and banter with it. But she's not staying silent.

title.children: 'Fiona is irrepressible': MND has taken Fiona's voice, but she's got more to say

title.children: 'No words to describe the grief': Family of pilot, three children killed in plane crash near Gundaroo ask for privacy

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: A close up photo of a man in a blue jacket holding a silver whistle

items.synopsis: Institutions that do the wrong thing usually do what they can to cover it up. That’s the force a whistleblower is up against, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Whistleblowers lose their jobs, marriages and sometimes their freedom. They should be protected, not punished

image.altText: A group of men in dark uniforms wearing helmets and holding military-style rifles stand beside an armoured vehicle on a road.

items.synopsis: Israel says it is at war as its soldiers battle Hamas fighters in the streets of southern Israel and launch air strikes on Gaza. Follow live.

title.children: As death toll passes 1,000, Gaza residents tell of ‘unbearable' fear and terror

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Ameera Harouda Gaza resident Maher Saeed Elyan, 58, told the ABC he hoped everything would be OK, but that residents were scared. "Last night [Saturday night] was extremely difficult, filled with tension and fear for children and women, and we couldn't sleep," he said. "The feeling was one of terror and fear that was unbearable. Both children and adults were feeling afraid. The Israeli occupation aims to instil fear and terror in the hearts of the citizens" When asked whether residents will abide by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's statement demanding they leave Gaza, Mr Saeed Elyan said the prime minister "is dreaming" and that residents will never leave. "We've been displaced once and twice, but this time, no. This will not happen. I am a refugee from Jaffa. I will not go anywhere. Will I go to Sinai? This will not happen. We will not leave our homes even if our homes are targeted and bombed."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: People in Gaza 'filled with fear'

children.content: Reporting by Ameera Harouda
Gaza resident Maher Saeed Elyan, 58, told the ABC he hoped everything would be OK, but that residents were scared.
"Last night [Saturday night] was extremely difficult, filled with tension and fear for children and women, and we couldn't sleep," he said.
"The feeling was one of terror and fear that was unbearable. Both children and adults were feeling afraid. The Israeli occupation aims to instil fear and terror in the hearts of the citizens"

props.alt: Two men sitting on concrete outside a building

children.content: (ABC News: Ameera Harouda)
When asked whether residents will abide by
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's
statement demanding they leave Gaza, Mr Saeed Elyan said the prime minister "is dreaming" and that residents will never leave.

"We've been displaced once and twice, but this time, no. This will not happen. I am a refugee from Jaffa. I will not go anywhere. Will I go to Sinai? This will not happen. We will not leave our homes even if our homes are targeted and bombed."

props.alt: Two men sitting on concrete outside a building, seen from a distance

children.content: (ABC News; Ameera Harouda)

image.altText: Two cricketers embrace.

items.synopsis: Virat Kohli makes the most of being dropped early in his innings to lead India to victory over Australia in their World Cup opener.

title.children: Kohli makes Australia pay for Marsh error in World Cup opener

image.altText: posting a letter

items.synopsis: Australians who can't attend a polling place on October 14 have just over 48 hours to apply for a postal vote pack.

title.children: Postal vote applications for the Voice referendum close on Wednesday. Here's who's eligible and how to apply.

image.altText: Vilimoni Botitu runs with the ball

items.synopsis: The Wallabies need Portugal to beat Fiji to have any chance of making the Rugby World Cup quarterfinals. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: Fiji and Portugal locked in low-scoring battle as Wallabies watch on

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Portugal have scored in the corner! Incredible! That kick and chase from Jerónimo Portela set up the field position. But then the kick through for Raffaele Storti to dot down under serious pressure is incredible! Portugal lead! AND THE CONVERSION IS GOOD! Portugal lead 10-3!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 45' Try Portugal!

children.content: Portugal have scored in the corner!
Incredible!
That kick and chase from Jerónimo Portela set up the field position.
But then the kick through for Raffaele Storti to dot down under serious pressure is incredible!
Portugal lead!
AND THE CONVERSION IS GOOD!
Portugal lead 10-3!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Well, hands up if you thought that would be the score at half time. No tries yet, but Portugal have looked most likely if we're going to be honest. They've had the territory and came oh so close to crossing the line. Fiji, meanwhile, have stuttered they way into the Portugal half on a couple of occasions, but haven't done much with it in all honesty. As things stand, the Wallabies are still going out, but I bet they are keeping a pretty close eye on what's happening from their base in Saint-Étienne.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fiji and Portugal locked at 3-3 at half time

children.content: (Getty Images)
Well, hands up if you thought that would be the score at half time.
No tries yet, but Portugal have looked most likely if we're going to be honest.
They've had the territory and came oh so close to crossing the line.
Fiji, meanwhile, have stuttered they way into the Portugal half on a couple of occasions, but haven't done much with it in all honesty.
As things stand, the Wallabies are still going out, but I bet they are keeping a pretty close eye on what's happening from their base in Saint-Étienne.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We've come back for an advantage though and this time Portugal go for the points on offer. We're all square at 3-3!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 38' Penalty Portugal

children.content: We've come back for an advantage though and this time Portugal go for the points on offer.
We're all square at 3-3!
